awd_titl_txt: Improving Student Performance and Engagement via the Human side of Engineering: Human Systems Engineering Education
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a growing need for engineers who can solve complex problems at the intersection of engineering and human behavior. Many of these problems affect the broad economic, defense, public health, and social well-being of the nation. For example, one of the National Academy of Engineering Grand Challenges for Engineering is to "secure cyberspace." Potential engineering solutions include better hardware, sensors, and secure programming languages. However, the National Academy of Engineering also directly targets "the psychology of computer users," including "how people interact with their computers, with the Internet, and with the information culture in general" as well as the "psychology and sociology that leads to deliberate computer crime." Human Systems Engineering education, training and instruction that integrates psychology and engineering, is hypothesized to prepare future engineers to better address human needs, goals, capabilities, and limitations. This approach is expected to ultimately result in engineered systems and solutions that are more functional, usable, empathic, and socially-engaged.

Project activities will include: (1) analyses of how student projects incorporate human-centered principles; (2) development and testing of lessons that infuse psychology into project-based engineering courses; and (3) a longitudinal evaluation of an introductory Human Systems Engineering course and students' perceptions of engineering, psychology, coursework, and careers. Findings from the first and second activities will reveal human-centered engineering principles that may otherwise be ignored in students' projects, and which offer critical targets for human systems engineering instruction. The second activity will begin to test instructional resources for filling those gaps. This effort will first identify particular examples, scenarios, and problems that can both inform and engage engineering students. Subsequently, researchers will generate free, field-tested, instructional modules that help students understand the synthesis of psychology and engineering. Findings from the third activity will shed light on students' beliefs about the role of psychology in engineering, reveal new ways to teach human-centered principles, and may contribute to better student engagement and retention. This activity will also adapt and validate a new survey-based measure of perceptions of engineering and engineering careers that takes into account Human Systems Engineering concepts and themes. All materials and findings will be disseminated via an interactive website that encourages community discussion.

por.por_cntn:
There is a great need for engineers and designers who can solve complicated problems that involve people and technology. These kinds of problems affect the economy, education, national defense, public health, and more. In the Human Systems Engineering (HSE) program at Arizona State University, students and faculty study and work on these issues. Our core belief is that training in human systems engineering helps students engage in human-centered engineering. This program prepares students for careers that advocate for the “human side” of engineering and design.

Intellectual Merit: This project contributed valuable insight into students’ knowledge and beliefs about human-centered engineering. One study looked at how introductory engineering students included psychological principles in their designs, such as thinking about users’ decisions or worries. We found that human-centered concepts were mostly neglected. Students focused mainly on their product instead of their future users. A survey-based study found that many students possessed only vague ideas about human-centered engineering, with particular gaps in knowledge about methods (the “how”) or value (the “why”). However, this research also showed high levels of openness and curiosity toward the field. Thus, we found that many future engineers are eager to learn about the human side of engineering, instead of being resistant or opposed to it. In addition, we saw that the field is wide open to introduce numerous engaging ideas. Students will benefit from diverse opportunities to learn about core principles of human-centered engineering, key methods and tools, and how this work adds value to numerous professional, scientific, and societal endeavors.

Broader Impacts: Multiple instructional strategies were developed to help future engineers and designers understand HSE and contributions of this field. One valuable strategy is an entry-level course, “Introduction to Human Systems Engineering” (HSE 101). In this class, students learn “basic principles, methods and theories of psychology and applications to engineering problems relevant to human systems” with “particular attention to the intersection of psychology and engineering.” Survey-based research found that students enrolled in this course are initially curious to learn about human-centered engineering, and the semester-long course reinforces this enthusiasm. Importantly, students finish the course with a greater appreciation for directly applying psychology within engineering.

Another strategy for strengthening students’ understanding is to engage them in defining and advocating for the field in their own terms. For instance, using project-based learning, a “Qualitative Research Methods” (HSE 390) course allows students to co-analyze real survey data (i.e., sourced and de-identified from this project) on learners’ beliefs about HSE. In developing qualitative coding rubrics, students in the course learn to develop their own perspectives on what HSE is, what HSE does, and how HSE improves outcomes.

Similarly, in “Designing for Learning” (HSE 427), students apply principles of instructional design to craft instructional videos. These videos are explicitly intended to communicate a psychological concept to an engineering audience. Thus, students in this class learn about human-centered instructional design and have the chance to advocate the field to others. Importantly, this effort paralleled our own work to create similar videos (e.g., on “Brainstorming,” “Creativity,” “Empathy,” and “Attitudes”). Several studies have affirmed that viewers can use the videos to learn about how these concepts and processes directly apply to engineering and design work.

Finally, in studying students’ attitudes and beliefs toward human-centered engineering, we recognized a need for students to learn about the potential societal value of HSE. Specifically, we saw the opportunity to teach students that HSE empowers them to understand and act on social inequities related to people and technology. This goal gave rise to several efforts.

First, an edited volume was developed and published on “Advancing Diversity, Equity, and Social Justice through Human Systems Engineering.” This award-winning book collected research, reviews, and personal narratives demonstrating the role of HSE (and related fields) in improving inclusion and equity. This book can now serve as an educational and inspirational resource for students, scholars, and the broader public.

Second, a new course was developed titled “Inclusive Engineering and Design” (HSE 598 and 494). In this course, students learn about (a) issues of bias and exclusion that permeate STEM work, (b) how bias can appear in engineering and design, and (c) how human-centered engineering can confront these issues. Students in this course have overwhelmingly expressed how it helped them gain or deepen their awareness of critical issues and potential solutions. Moreover, the course also revealed exemplar topics (e.g., hostile design) that other instructors can use to spark engagement with their own students.

In sum, this project employed diverse approaches to understand students’ attitudes and needs toward human-centered engineering. Inspired by these findings and opportunities, we explored several instructional strategies for communicating key ideas in Human Systems Engineering. All of these approaches have the potential to be broadly adopted or adapted in other programs and settings.
